Dear Mr. Hogue:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action did not result in
compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation

Additional Findings Yes

Special Investigation Results given by telephone to Director 1t

ALLEGATION:
Youth are placed at facilities next door to each other. Youth touched the inside of
another youth's thigh while fully clothed. No further details are known.
INVESTIGATION:
Director 1, Youth A (female, age 13), Youth B (male, age 13) and Youth C (male,
age 17) were interviewed at the facility on March 22, 2021.
Director 1 said that this incident was reported when the four youth, two from South
Bluff Teaching Family Home and two from Indian River Teaching Family Home,
were together at the South Bluff facility. Director said there was video and supplied
me with a USB drive with video of the time the alleged incident took place.
The video shows the staff coming to the doorway of the den, standing in the den,
and bringing food to the youth. The staff gave medications to one of the youth.
The video supplied by the facility had three one-hour segments. The video shows
Youth C arranging the couches in the den of South Bluff. The den has three wooden
couches. Youth C arranged the couches in a U shape and there a bean bag type
chair in the middle of the U shape. Youth enters the den at 7:31 p.m. according to
the date stamp on the video. The three other youth, Youth A, Youth B and Youth D
(female, age 17) all take positions in the den by 7:35 p.m. The four youth are
watching a movie until Youth C reports that Youth A is inappropriately touching
Youth B and the boys are returned to Indian River. The time stamp on the video
show about 8:40 p.m.
The staff are seen in the living area in front of the den only on occasion. Former
Staff 9 enters the den at 7:35 p.m. and leans on the door jam for two minutes. The
camera angle is such that I cannot tell if the staff were on the couches outside of the
den as reported by Direct Care 6. If the staff were sitting on the couches in the living
area, they would not have had a very good view of the four youth. Three of the youth
were laying out on these wooden couches with high sides covered with blankets.
The fourth youth was on the floor sitting on a bean bag type piece of furniture also
covered with a blanket. Although the video does not show where the staff are
seated, the angle from outside the den is such that the youth were not being
sufficiently supervised.
Direct Care 6 sent an email regarding the incident on March 25, 2021 and was
interviewed by telephone on May 04, 2021. She said that she was in the office doing
paperwork and the other two staff were on the couches watching the four youth
watch a movie.

Youth B said that nothing had happened, and Youth C had made a report because
he was mad at Youth A because she did not want to be his girlfriend. Youth B said
that Youth A touched his knee and not his upper thigh. He said they were in the den
at South Bluff watching a movie on Saturday. Youth B said that while they were
watching a movie the staff were either standing on sitting outside the den.
Youth A said that the youth from the two programs were watching a movie on
Saturday night in the den. She said she did not touch Youth B inappropriately. Youth
A said she had been placed at South Bluff for four months. She said that nothing
happened. She said she was mad at Youth C and there was a safety plan that she
could not talk to Youth C. She said she said “that gives me butterflies” but she was
not talking about Youth B, but about a character in the movie. Youth B said the staff
were sitting just outside the den.
Youth C said that he saw Youth A touch Youth B on the upper thigh on Saturday
about 8 p.m. while they were in the den at South Bluff watching a movie. Youth C
said he got up and reported this to Staff 2. He said that the staff there at the time
said it was time to go and they went back to Indian River.
I received a call back from DHHS Worker 5 on March 25, 2021, who is Youth B’s
DHHS worker, and she said she had talked with Youth B and developed a safety
plan even though Youth B told her that nothing happened. She said Youth B told her
that he has no interest in Youth A.
I called Direct Care 6 on March 25, 2021. She said three staff were supervising four
youth. The group, two boys from Indian River and two girls from South Bluff, were on
an outing and then came back and were in the den at South Bluff watching a movie.
She said staff were supervising the youth sitting outside the den on the couches that
are there. She said Youth C reported that Youth A touched Youth B. At that point,
the staff took the two boys back to Indian River.
I called Indian River on May 3, 2021 and spoke with Staff 8. He said that Former
Staff 9 had left employment at Indian River and Former Staff 9 last day was April 16,
2021.
A document titled “Safety Plan for (Youth C) was received via email on March 23,
2021. It read as follows: Best efforts will be made to keep Youth A and Youth C to
have minimal, to no contact with one another. All parties agree that at no time will
Youth A and Youth C be alone in the presence of one another. These efforts will
include in transportation seating chart, monitoring of youth laptops and that more
efforts are being made to ensure the houses are not combined for activities in the
future.” This safety plan was signed and dated by Director 1 on March 8, 2021.
The reason given for why the two houses (Indian River Teaching Family Home and
South Bluff Teaching Family Home) were combined on March 20, 2021 was that
there were only three staff.

I called Direct Care 6 on May 4, 2021. She said she was in the office mostly on
March 20, 2021. The other staff were in the den with the four youth or right outside
facing the den. She said that before she came to work the staff had combined the
two houses. She said that she was told later that it was not allowed to combine the
houses.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: Based on the video recording and interviews, clearly South Bluff
and Indian River were combined on March 20, 2021, which was
in violation of the above rule, because there were only three
staff for the two CCI programs. Additionally, based on the video,
the staff were not closely observing these youth as they laid on
couches and a bean bag chair covered with blankets, with the
couches positioned in such a way the staff could not observe
what was going on.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
Director 1 who is responsible for the on-site day to day operation of South Bluff
Teaching Family Home and Indian River Teaching Family Home signed a safety
plan which stated the two houses were not to be combined, yet on March 20, 2021
due to lack of staff the two Child Caring Institutions were combined.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4116 Chief administrator; responsibilities.
(1) An agency shall assign the chief administrator
responsibility for the on-site day-to-day operation of the
institution and for ensuring compliance with these rules.
ANALYSIS: Based on the video and interviews South Bluff and Indian River
were combined on March 20, 2021, in non-compliance with the
safety plan that was signed by Director 1, the chief
administrator, on March 8, 2021.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that upon the receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan,
there be no change to the licensing status of this private child caring institution.
